title: Bear wanders into a Colorado man's backyard to roll around in the snow and play with a soccer ball
text:
A playful bear in Colorado took a break from preparing for hibernation to play with a soccer ball on a snowy day.

The bear wandered into the backyard of Boulder resident Scott Willhite who captured the surprising moment.

He told Storyful that he was inside home with two sons when the furry animal waltzed into view on Sunday.

'I was talking on the phone when I suddenly saw a bear walking through the backyard,' he said.

Scott Willhite of Boulder, Colorado, captured the moment a black bear (pictured) rolled around in the snow and played with a soccer ball in his backyard

The video shows the bear tearing into a soccer ball next to the family's trampoline as it rolls around on the snow covered ground.

Pieces of snow and foam get caught in his fur as Willhite's two boys looked on in awe.

He said: 'The boys loved it and could not stop giggling. The ball, however, did not fare well.'

Pictured: The bear lounging in Willhite's backyard as he and his two sons watch from inside their home

One person joked that 'there's a child in the house who's going to need a new soccer ball for Christmas!'

People on social media fell in love with the rambunctious bear.

One woman wrote: 'We can all learn from animals. Even though they have to work hard to gather food and feed their families, they still take time to “live in the moment“ and play and enjoy life!'

Another said: 'Cuteness Overload... From a distance of course.'

One person joked about the destroyed soccer ball.

He said: 'I think there's a child in the house who's going to need a new soccer ball for Christmas!'

The National Weather Service reported that some parts of Boulder received 7.5 inches of snow on Sunday.

Later this year, this black bear (pictured) and other bears will go into hibernation until mid-March

Earlier this month, Colorado saw a surprise burst of snowfall after temperatures dropped from the 70s to the 20s in just 24 hours.

Roadways became hectic and authorities recorded at least 200 car crashes in Denver alone.

As the weather becomes colder, black bears will begin to hibernate.

The Colorado Parks & Wildlife say that black bears are the only type of bear found in the state and there were as many as 20,000 bears as of 2016.

Bears will go into hibernation around November and will typically not emerge until mid-March.
description: Scott Willhite of Boulder, Colorado, captured the cute moment a black bear wandered into his backyard to roll around in the snow and play with his sons soccer ball on October 26
